Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mapping interactions mediated by secondary metabolites in a fungus-growing ant microbiome
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most microbes produce small molecule secondary metabolites as signals and/or antibiotics that control interactions between species. Despite their immense medical importance, the natural diversity and function of these molecules remains obscure. This prevents a full understanding of how microbial communities maintain critical ecosystem functions such as healthy host-microbe relationships. To further understand these systems, this project will generate networks of microbial interactions and their associated secondary metabolites based on the co-occurrence of particular microbes and secondary metabolites in environmental samples. Work will be conducted on the fungus-growing ant Trachymyrmex septentrionalis as an experimental model for these studies, profiling host-microbe interactions that are mediated by secondary metabolites within ant colonies collected throughout the Eastern USA. The T. septentrionalis symbiosis will also be utilized to broadly demonstrate the basics of animal-microbe interactions via a public display that will be linked to newly designed web resources. In addition, postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers will be trained in microbiology and chemical ecology, including members of underrepresented groups. This project will therefore broadly advance understanding of the diversity and natural function of secondary metabolites and their impacts of host-microbe interactions.

Nearly all microbes produce secondary metabolites. These molecules are particularly common in symbioses, where they mediate host-microbe interactions. Such interactions are typically studied using low-throughput approaches that remove secondary metabolite-producing organisms from their natural communities. These experiments are therefore insufficient to determine in situ secondary metabolite diversity, and cannot unambiguously link specific molecules to the ecological interactions that they naturally mediate. To overcome these limitations, this project will develop an approach to comprehensively identify interspecific interactions mediated by secondary metabolites by identifying patterns of co-variation between interacting taxa and the secondary metabolites that mediate these interactions, using the fungus-growing ant Trachymyrmex septentrionalis as an experimental model. In this approach, taxa that interact mutualistically will co-occur with both each other and the metabolite that mediates this mutualistic interaction. Reciprocally, taxa that interact antagonistically will rarely co-occur, and the metabolite that mediates this antagonistic interaction will co-occur with the producing taxon but not the target taxon. In situ interactions will be recapitulated using laboratory ant colonies microbial cultures. Researchers at various levels will be trained in these molecular and chemical ecology methods and museum and online resources to disseminate results to the broader public will be developed. Together, this project will provide a methodological approach to map interactions mediated by secondary metabolites in microbial communities and identify the in situ functions of such molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our central hypothesis in this project was that interactions mediated by secondary metabolites in Trachymyrmex septentrionalis fungus gardens can be inferred from patterns of co-variation between taxa and secondary metabolites in this symbiosis. 

As a strategy to map secondary metabolites present in entire Trachymyrmex septentrionalis fungus gardens, liquid chromatography – tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) data were acquired from samples collected across the East of USA. The generated data set was analyzed using molecular network workflow (https://gnps.ucsd.edu/ProteoSAFe/static/gnps-splash.jsp). Briefly, this approach uses tandem mass-spectrometry (MS/MS) to determine the molecular mass of ionizable metabolites in a sample, and clusters related metabolites based on the similarity of their fragmentation patterns. By comparing these mass spectra with those of known compounds (GNPS libraries), the chemical diversity of a sample can be surveyed and prioritized for further analysis. By applying molecular network to Trachymyrmex septentrionalis fungus gardens samples; fungal, bacterial and plant metabolites were identified. Since most of the detected molecules remain to be identified, development of bioinformatics tools for in silico annotations contribute furthermore to this purpose.

During the progress of this project we built new mass spectrometry analysis software to allow a deeper understanding of the molecules found in the fungus gardens. We performed bidimensional (2D) and tridimensional (3D) mapping (molecular cartography) and provided interpretation of the chemistry in fungus gardens from two species, Atta texana and Trachymyrmex septentrionalis. We learned that these gardens behave as external digestive systems to provide nutrients the ants cannot produce by themselves.

Initial results from this project were used to assess the Network Annotation Propagation (NAP) tool available through the GNPS platform (https://gnps.ucsd.edu/ProteoSAFe/static/gnps-theoretical.jsp). The publication including these results describes the improvement in the annotation of metabolites through in silico annotations. See publication da Silva, R. R. et al. Propagating annotations of molecular networks using in silico fragmentation. PLoS Comput Biol 14, e1006089 (2018).

Datasets from this study were part of the development of a tool used to search single mass spectrum in order to contextualize and provide insights regarding other datasets where the molecules from any study can be also present. In the case of samples from T. septentrionalis fungus gardens, molecules from known bacteria were found using this tool suggesting potential roles of these bacteria in fungus gardens. An associated video can be accessed through the following link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Zb5gZIabBU&ab_channel=DorresteinLab. The tool is available through the GNPS platform (https://gnps.ucsd.edu/ProteoSAFe/static/gnps-theoretical.jsp) and the corresponding publication is also available as Wang, M. et al. Mass spectrometry searches using MASST. Nat Biotechnol 38, 23–26 (2020).

Datasets derived from the study of these fungus gardens were also part of community efforts for reanalysis and co-analysis of public mass spectrometry-based metabolomics data and associated metadata. The tool is available as part of the GNPS platform (https://redu.ucsd.edu/) and published as Jarmusch, A. K. et al. ReDU: a framework to find and reanalyze public mass spectrometry data. Nat. Methods 17, 901–904 (2020).

We are currently working on finalizing two manuscripts that include the 3D mapping of A. texana (Figure 1) and Trachymyrmex septentrionalis colonies (Figure 2).  

All the datasets derived from this project have been deposited in MassIVE repository and are publicly available for the community. We built 3D maps from ants´ colonies of two species (Atta texana and Trachymyrmex septentrionalis) and performed experiments demonstrating the susceptibility of ants´ colonies to pathogens.

In summary, besides learning that these gardens behave as external digestive systems to provide nutrients to the ants, our results enable to confirm the presence of microbial metabolites in situ, which is fundamental to hypothesize the potential role of these molecules in natural environments. Besides that, bioactive metabolites from fungal pathogens suggest their involvement in pathogenic process not yet described for Trachymyrmex septentrionalis fungus gardens. Future work using the acquired public dataset will provide further responses for the role of small molecules from these ecosystems.
